text: hello I'm Nathan Grinnell and I am Byron
Howard and we are the directors of
Disney's Tangled we're going to show you
a progression reel of how animation
comes to life here at the Disney
Animation Studios so it all begins with
the story sketch it begins in a story
room with about six or seven artists and
we sit around the table and where we're
trying to develop who these characters
are what their personalities are what
this world is we develop the pacing and
the tone of the film it's to make a
blueprint of what we'll be producing
from that point forward the next stage
is rough animation and this is where the
characters really come to life at this
point we've recorded the actors voices
the we've acted this stuff out in front
of our animators neethu and I will get
up and be Rapunzel and Flynn and they'll
try to you know mimic our moves and
other moves as well and you know an
animator here at Disney will produce
anywhere from 2 to 5 seconds of
animation per week and next up we have
hair simulation you know I'm for most
animated films the animator would take
care of the the hair animation as well
as the character animation on this movie
because of the complication with dealing
with 70 feet of hair we had to have a
whole nother team come in to to take
care of Rapunzel's hair it was an
incredibly complicated process
this stage is Herod cloth finally you'll
see some amazing cloth simulation going
on very realistic cloth you'll also
notice that the thousand strands of
spaghetti like hair that you saw in the
last clip have now turned into one
hundred thousand strands of actual CG
hair and this starts to approach what
the final look of the film will be and
here we are final color we we kind of
consider this to be the icing on the
cake if you will we this is where this
is a stage where everything kind of
comes together and really comes to life
it's it's what will be up on the screen
for audiences to see and one of the one
of the most important stages of
production
and you know in talking about this
process as simple as it was to kind of
go through these stages it is an
incredibly challenging process that
takes 500 people to produce and we were
very proud of the results
